description.narrative: De-legitimize the use of terror by seeking to highlight the fundamental immorality, costs, and negative impacts of using violence and to emphasize the benefits of using peaceful, tolerant alternatives.

title.narrative: HED Partnership: Recruiting Employable Students at the University with Management Education (RESUME)

description.narrative: Mentouri University, Constantine Algeria/University of Michigan William Davidson Institute: Recruiting Employable Students at the University with Management Education (RESUME) - The William Davidson Institute (WDI) at the University of Michigan (UM), the Stephen M. Ross School of Business and the English Language Institute at UM, partnered with the University of Mentouri Constantine (UMC) to provide effective teaching, curriculum, and research in English and Management. Using a strategy that combined experiential learning, knowledge creation, and real-world experience, the partners created a career center and developed an English-language training curriculum. Together, the partners enhanced the capacity of the faculty to develop and teach a modern Management curriculum that actively engages the private sector. With the overall goal of increasing the employability of UMC student.

title.narrative: Harnessing Youth Leadership and Improving Education Outcomes in the Middle East

description.narrative: (USAID Middle East Regional (MER)): The Harnessing Youth Leadership to Improve Education Outcomes Activity is a $1.4 million program implemented by Teach for All (TFALL) to channel youth leadership towards strengthening and promoting education for children in the Middle East region. Teach for All will work with university graduates to provide opportunities for them to support classroom-based and non-formal learning, such as providing remedial support. The organization will also help to launch and grow locally- rooted, national organizations that enlist their nation's most promising young leaders to commit to a foundational and skill-building experience of two years of classroom teaching that will increase student access to learning opportunities. These newly launched organizations will work in partnership with local communities and government officials to foster sustainable changes to the education systems. More specifically, USAID assistance will continue to support Teach for Morocco and expand Teach for Lebanon's (TFL) efforts to reach high-need students (including refugees), improve capacity to measure results, and function as a lighthouse organization demonstrating the potential of TFALL's approach to others in the region. In addition, TFALL will support prospective partners in the Middle East to launch new network programs in Libya and Tunisia. This mechanism will program $54,076 towards the Basic Education earmark and $30,000 towards girls in conflict.

(USAID Middle East Regional (MER)): In many contexts, violence and the incitement of violence targeting communities or individuals based on their identity as a member of a religious and ethnic minority population (REM), characterize atrocity crimes (including genocide, war crimes, crimes against humanity, and ethnic cleansing). Oftentimes, this type of violence and discrimination against particular REM populations also constitutes an early warning sign and risk factor for mass atrocities. This activity will reduce the risk of atrocities against religious and ethnic minorities in Libya, Yemen, Tunisia, and Morocco by improving atrocity recognition and communication, prevention, and response. MER programming will support the achievement of three objectives: 1) Conduct Atrocity Risk Assessment and Identify Early Warning and other Prevention and Response Mechanisms for at-risk REM Populations; 2) Pilot an Early Warning System based on Recommendations for at-risk REM populations; and 3) Support Additional Atrocity Prevention, Response, and Recovery Efforts for REM populations. The implementing partner will accomplish the first objective through country-specific research products with actionable recommendations analyzing atrocity risks, barriers to services, and existing approaches to atrocity early warning systems. This analysis will feed into the attainment of the second objective, which will pilot these recommendations in one or more countries. The activity will reach the third objective through capacity building for civil society and local government as well as rapid responses/small grants to enable recipients to respond quickly to unanticipated needs that arise among REM communities. title.narrative: MENA Regional Drought Management System II

description.narrative: (USAID Middle East Regional (MER)): MENA countries are experiencing growing water security challenges. These challenges are exacerbated by climate change characterized by higher temperatures, increased evapotranspiration rates, and changes in precipitation patterns exemplified as intense droughts and floods. Droughts affect all water users, with the most critical actions demanding a focus on maintaining drinking water supplies for the populace. WASH is always the number one priority for any water that is available. ..Since droughts affect water availability and quality, the absence of fully functioning, integrated drought management systems hinders the capacity to predict, plan, and proactively manage droughts in a way that supports continuation of WASH services. In response, MENADrought works with a range of agencies and government departments in Jordan, Lebanon, and Morocco, including those tasked with the provision of water supply and sanitation services during drought conditions. Realizing the direct correlation between drought management and water security, MENADrought enhances drought monitoring and seasonal forecasting capabilities; conducts drought impact and vulnerability mapping; and advances national and regional efforts to operationalize effective drought policy and preparedness planning. These efforts collectively empower decision-makers to plan for and manage the impacts of droughts on water and food security and accelerate the development of drought-related decrees and strategies fostering adoption of a robust integrated water management approach in the targeted countries. Given that droughts amplify inequalities in access to water services, MENADrought also aims to reduce the negative impact droughts have on vulnerable communities through developing appropriate resilience and climate adaptation measures to support water and agricultural security in these communities. $500,000 in funding goes towards the Water earmark.

sector.narrative: Water supply and sanitation - large systems
Water supply and sanitation - large systems

description.narrative: (USAID Middle East Regional (MER)): The MEDRC Humanitarian Desalination Challenge will focus on the development of a market-ready, low-cost desalination device for individual and family use in MENA countries. The Challenge Program will be implemented along two tracks. The prize portion of the challenge will be funded by the Government of Oman and is structured to encourage applicants to focus on new small-scale desalination processes for individual users. USAID is funding the Pathways Research component that will encourage users to develop a larger, family-sized desalination device that may serve as a precursor to the small-scale device. The MEDRC challenge is designed to develop technologies to desalinate a range of source water, including brackish groundwater and seawater. Given that reserves of brackish water are large and widely distributed across the MENA region, the proposed research and technology should be of potential benefit to a wider population than if restricted to seawater alone.

(USAID Middle East Regional (MER)): In collaboration with MENAdrought, this activity builds upon the success of the MENA Regional Drought Management System to strengthen drought monitoring, forecasting,, planning, management and policy. In particular, through this funding, NASA Goddard Space Flight Center (NASA GSFC) will deliver capabilities for advanced drought monitoring and forecasting. In the final year of the activity, NASA GSFC will focus on ope-rationalizing the forecasting system customized for MENA countries. The NASA program will enhance national and local capacity in the MENA region to develop and implement drought management plans and drought resilience strategies to reduce drought impacts on food supply and on the quantity and safety of the water supply to vulnerable communities.

description.narrative: The Water and Development Alliance (WADA), a public-private partnership between USAID and the Coca-Cola system to address community water needs in developing countries around the world. This next phase of WADA will build on 12 years of partnership and will continue its in-country programming, with ongoing programs in Madagascar and Nigeria and a program currently under development in Tanzania. In addition to country programs focus areas on water quality, women's economic empowerment and leveraging both public and private sector core capacities. WADA II plans to share lessons learned from the partners and the programs through a variety of outlets, including the newly launched website, conference presentations (such as UNC or Stockholm WWW), a series of webinars to engage both local and global leaders, and the release of white papers highlighting opportunities for the U.S. public and private sectors to engage to improve the water and sanitation sectors.

description.narrative: Support and strengthen negotiation processes and implement peace and reconciliation processes, accords and ceasefire agreements at track levels 1, 2 and 3, including support to indigenous peacebuilding efforts. Illustrative activities include negotiation training; platform development; public opinion polling; facilitation activities; elder statesperson engagement; provision of international expert advice and knowledge; financial support to parties; multi-stakeholder dialogues; assistance with the design of peacebuilding training programs; support and maintenance of agreed verification mechanisms; support to complaint tracking mechanisms; and work with local and national government representatives to connect to their constituencies. This includes support to locally-driven peace processes and conflict mitigation strategies in order to address grievances, build community cohesion, strengthen the relationship between the community, local, and national government stakeholders and support local conflict resolution mechanisms, including mediation and community dialogues. Reconciliation processes may involve: dialogue processes with trained facilitators, engagement of religious and/or community leaders, the utilization of local cultural practices, reconciliation commissions, media/ expressive and/or performing arts such as theater and TV/ radio shows with culturally specific and targeted story lines and/or other educational activities. Support the media, both traditional and social media, during conflict to peace transitions in order to ensure balance, transparency, and accountability and amplify positive peace messages. Includes: supporting innovative media programs that inform and prepare people to accept the outcome of credible negotiations and encourage them to engage in peace efforts; creating better understanding between parties or identity groups and their followers including providing forums for dialogue; educating the public about negotiation or democratic proc

description.narrative: USAID and Alkarma Edutainment, a leading Egyptian production firm, have teamed up with the regions largest satellite broadcaster to produce a compelling and educational drama for the regions 100 million young people. The University is an Arabic youngadult drama series, which follows a group of students at a university in the Arab region as they deal with the pressures of life, family, and school in a global society. The character profiles and story lines are based on intensive polling and focus group research with more than 3,500 young people across the region. The program was developed using a team of writers from across the region and consultants from the BBC and Hollywood.
A Cooperative Agreement with Search for Common Ground to produce a new dramatic television series (30 episodes) that will be called Madame President aims at empowering Arab Women.

title.narrative: Middle East Water Security Initiative - BAA Activity 1

description.narrative: (USAID Middle East Regional (MER)): USAID will support a two-year activity to promote a holistic water solution for twenty underserved and refugee host communities in Lebanon and Jordan. The result will be provision of potable water at the community and household levels through cutting-edge technology, sustainable business models, empowered women entrepreneurs, and public and private partners in their respective communities. Clean water will be generated via community-based kiosks and air-to-water technology that converts atmospheric water vapor into clean drinking water at the household level. This is one of three awards that will be finalized in FY 2016 from the Broad Agency Announcement (BAA) process, which was identified as IM #57099 in the FY 2015 OP.

description.narrative: The Middle East Regional Cooperation (MERC) Program was established in 1981 to facilitate research collaboration between Egyptian and Israeli scientists after their two countries signed the Camp David Accords. The program expanded to include Jordan, Morocco, Tunisia, Lebanon, the West Bank and Gaza Strip in 1993. Today, at a time of rapid change in the Arab world, MERC continues to bring together Arab and Israeli scientists and students to create and share solutions to regional development challenges while promoting a peaceful exchange between neighbors.

title.narrative: Regional Water Management Benchmarking in MENA Region

description.narrative: This 18 month $1.5 million task order addresses non-structural methods of assisting Middle East North Africa (MENA) region with aridity and a shortage of renewable freshwater resources. Population growth and increasing demands for food, housing and jobs place extreme pressures on water resources throughout the region.

Program funds will support the International Center for Biosaline Agriculture as a regional hub for generating and disseminating data. Through the development of regional networks, knowledge and data on cutting-edge concepts and modeling capabilities is transferred, thereby increasing scientific input into the policy process.

The Middle East Regional Cooperation (MERC) Program was established in 1981 to facilitate research collaboration between Egyptian and Israeli scientists after their two countries signed the Camp David Accords. The program expanded to include Jordan, Morocco, Tunisia, Lebanon, the West Bank and Gaza Strip in 1993. Today, at a time of rapid change in the Arab world, MERC continues to bring together Arab and Israeli scientists and students to create and share solutions to regional development challenges while promoting a peaceful exchange between neighbors.

title.narrative: Interagency Agreement with State for Research Grants under the Middle East Regional Program (MERC)

description.narrative: Interagency Agreement (IAA) with the U.S. Department of State for Funding of Selected Research Grants under the Middle East Regional Program(MERC). Grants encourage Arab and Israeli scientists to collaborate in solving problems constraining development in the Middle East region. By combining expertise in agriculture, biomedical research, engineering, social sciences, and natural resources management, Arab and Israeli scientists have been able to address common problems more effectively in a regional approach, while at the same time promoting peaceful coexistence in the Middle East. The MERC Program was created in the aftermath of the original Camp David Peace Accords and is administered by the USAID. This program funds applied research aimed at solving regional development problems, and seeks projects that are likely to contribute to development in an estimated time frame of ten years or less.

title.narrative: Elections and Political Processes - Legal and Institutional Framework

description.narrative: Elections and Political Processes - Develop impartial legal frameworks for elections and political processes including the laws, regulations, and constitutional provisions that govern them (election system design, boundary delimitation, election laws). It includes the development of laws and regulatory frameworks for a competitive, representative, multi-party system including laws, regulations, and constitutional provisions governing political parties and other political entities.

title.narrative: Constitutions, Laws, and Legal Systems - Public Knowledge and Understanding of the Rule of Law

description.narrative: Justice System - Support educational and training institutions and programs for all justice system actors, to include reform of pedagogy and curricula, continuing and in-service training, and international partnerships; support of attestation, certification, and other standard-setting mechanisms; support of legal professional associations to promote professionalism, dignity, and public service; and strengthen oversight, including through institutions (judicial councils, inspectors general, ombudsmen, and disciplinary bodies), policies (ethics, internal integrity, and whistleblowers), and procedures (citizen oversight).

description.narrative: Strengthen the legal, regulatory, institutional, and information environment which protects and enables the growth in associational life and the development of independent and sustainable civil society organizations (CSOs). Build the capacity of civil society organizations to act as agents for reform and support their participation in democratic decision-making through articulating and representing their members interests, engaging in service delivery, and advocating for issues which become part of the public agenda and are reflected in public policies. Encourage the strengthening of a civic culture which supports democratic institutions and processes, active participation in political and civic life, and the civic virtues of tolerance, pluralism, compromise, trust, and respect for individual rights, including gender equality.

Improve the capacity and sustainability of civil and criminal justice sector actors and institutions, enhance coordination amongst them, develop citizen demand for an effective and accountable justice system, and develop associations to advocate for all citizens. Justice sector actors and institutions include: police, border security, prosecutors, forensics experts, judges, court personnel, public defenders, corrections personnel, private bar, law schools, legal professional associations, and training institutions for each of them. Work towards an equitable justice system by ensuring equality before the law, fair trial standards, and other elements of procedural fairness. Ensure more equitable access to justice through innovations within and beyond the state system and through improvements in the quality and quantity of justice services, with a particular focus on women, youth, the poor, and other marginalized or vulnerable groups. Programs primarily focused on trafficking in persons or migrant smuggling should be included in element 5.3 under the Transnational Crime area in the Peace and Security Objective.

description.narrative: Promote governance institutions, processes, and policies that are transparent and accountable across all development sectors. Support non-governmental as well as governmental institutions (including enforcement and investigation entities, independent audit agencies, anti-corruption commissions, procurement agencies, legislatures, line ministries, independent agencies, political parties, judicial actors, as well as civil society organizations, academia, press and the private sector). Support civic education and advocacy for reform of laws and practices or directly improving accountability and transparency of governance processes covering various development sectors.

title.narrative: Civic Participation - Civil Society Capacity for Democratic Processes

description.narrative: Civic Participation - Strengthen the capacity of CSOs for policy analysis, advocacy, coalition-building, internal governance, membership representation and services, and engage in other activities aimed at fostering more peaceful and democratic societies. CSOs include, but are not limited to, human rights organizations, womens groups, labor unions, business and professional associations, youth movements, religious organizations, indigenous organizations, think tanks, and organizations representing vulnerable populations. Areas of capacity building may include, but are not limited to, technical expertise (e.g. human rights, legal reform); CSO self-regulation (e.g. establishing NGO Codes of Conduct); organizational capacity (e.g. strategic planning, financial management and accountability, public relations, issue management, and outreach, revenue generation, accountable fundraising); and targeted advocacy training and technical assistance.

description.narrative: USAID's Higher Education Solutions Network (HESN) harnesses the ingenuity and passion of university students, researchers, and faculty to develop innovative solutions to the global development challenges we face, ranging from ~improving healthcare delivery services, to better understanding the connection between poverty, conflict and food insecurity. ~~Each of the eight HESN Development Labs focuses on understanding and uncovering solutions to a designated problem. The ConDev Center at Texas A&M University aims to increase the efficiency, efficacy, and impact of USAID development policies and programs in fragile and conflict-affected societies through multidisciplinary applied research and engagement activities by harnessing the innovative power of Texas A&M University and partner research institutions, universities, and organizations in host countries.

title.narrative: Expanding Farm Advisory Services (formerly Farmer Innovations GDA)

description.narrative: "Expanding Farm Advisory Services" is a sub-award under a Global Development Alliance (GDA) in partnership with the Skoll Foundation. The local partner, Proximity Designs, will scale up its proven model for delivering farm advisory services to 28 townships over the next three years, reaching an estimated 250,000 farmers with increased incomes by $50 to $200 per farm household..The activity will reach townships in the Ayeyarwady and the Dry Zone, where 85 percent of farmers are located and will focus on the rice value chain. Assistance will be used to develop new products and services such as farm business management, and weather and market information. User-centered research will be conducted to apply innovative approaches to products, services and digital offerings, creating more opportunities to grow farm enterprises. To achieve scale, the activity will move to a new multi-channel platform using mobile technology, agro-dealers, lead farmers, video, and radio.

description.narrative: Improve the capacity and sustainability of civil and criminal justice sector actors and institutions, enhance coordination amongst them, develop citizen demand for an effective and accountable justice system, and develop associations to advocate for all citizens. Justice sector actors and institutions include: police, border security, prosecutors, forensics experts, judges, court personnel, public defenders, corrections personnel, private bar, law schools, legal professional associations, and training institutions for each of them. Work towards an equitable justice system by ensuring equality before the law, fair trial standards, and other elements of procedural fairness. Ensure more equitable access to justice through innovations within and beyond the state system and through improvements in the quality and quantity of justice services, with a particular focus on women, youth, the poor, and other marginalized or vulnerable groups. Programs primarily focused on trafficking in persons or migrant smuggling should be included in element 5.3 under the Transnational Crime area in the Peace and Security Objective.

title.narrative: Testing the Effectiveness of Tailored NFE Interventions Promoting Critical Thinking and Emotional Literacy in the Middle East

description.narrative: The broad objectives of Testing the Effectiveness of Tailored NFE Interventions Promoting Critical Thinking and Emotional Literacy in the Middle East are first to evaluate the barriers that have limited the success of non-formal education (NFE) across the Middle East and North Africa, particularly as applies to critical thinking and emotional literacy, by jointly developing a battery of questions to be included on nationally representative public opinion surveys. Secondly, it plans to use this information to design interventions on critical thinking and emotional literacy that are tailored to specific regions and conditions, and to test the effectiveness of these interventions. The hypothesis being tested is that interventions that have taken local knowledge and attitudes into consideration in their design will be more successful than standard interventions. The goal is to be able to design specific interventions that are tailored to specific countries and, as possible, sub-regions of countries. The program will test the effectiveness for direct interventions in Jordan and Lebanon that could be scaled to other parts of the region, including Morocco, Algeria, Egypt, the West Bank and Gaza, Algeria, and Tunisia in the future.

title.narrative: Co-Creating ELearning Solutions for Children in NFE in the Middle East

description.narrative: The objective of Co-Creating eLearning Solutions for Children in NFE in the Middle East is to pilot an innovative eLearning intervention which embeds psychosocial support and life skills for children into existing NFE programs in Jordan and Lebanon with the support of local partners. The proposed research also intends to measure learning outcomes and to map the relationship between learning outcomes and psychosocial support and well-being through the use of the e-learning intervention.

title.narrative: Technical and Administrative Support for the Middle East Regional Cooperation and Cooperative Development Research Programs (support contract for MERC)

description.narrative: This contract provides technical and administrative support to USAID for the Middle East Regional Cooperation (MERC) Program. Under the direction of USAID, the contractor recruits external peer-review panels of scientists knowledgeable in the field(s) of each invited proposal and provides a site for the panels to meet; assists USAID in summarizing panel results; follows up with prospective grantees to ensure that they adequately respond to all provisos placed on their proposals and provide all requested support materials; assists USAID in technical monitoring of approximately 40 grants in the field; provides liaison and answers questions from grantees and applicants; and provides general administrative support for the programs including logistical support for internal review committees at USAID, the maintenance of updated databases of projects and reviewers, and backup files and on each proposal and funded project.
Personnel (Cross-cutting): Vendor implementing services for U.S. Agency for International Development.

title.narrative: Middle East Water Security Initiative - BAA Activity 2

description.narrative: The Acceleration of Aquifer Storage and Recovery (ASR) activity improves water security in the Middle East through the application and dissemination of new methods for mapping and identifying high potential ASR sites using remote sensing, geospatial data, and hydrologic analysis. The activity will not construct new ASR infrastructure, but rather will apply new site selection methods over wide areas to substantially reduce the cost of identifying and characterizing sites. This will benefit both host government and development partner agencies to support cost-effective solutions to capture large amounts of water that would otherwise be lost through runoff for both drinking water and other economic (industrial and agricultural) activities. The target study area will include watershed regions across Jordan, Lebanon, and the West Bank.

title.narrative: Prevention and Response to Gender Based Violence in the Middle East

description.narrative: This is a three year flexible program that is designed for the region and its complexities and that recognizes immediate term achievements help advance the medium and longer term goals necessary to noticeably reduce gender based violence (GBV). This program will provide tailored responses to address GBV in those countries in active conflict and crises and in those countries undergoing political transition in various forms. Substantively, the program will address issues around prevention, protection and response, as appropriate to the situation on the ground. Baseline research and changing ground dynamics will determine final programming decisions. However, it is planned that in those countries engaged in/responding to active conflict and crisis, over the immediate, medium and long term, illustrative programming may include: strengthening and institutionalizing ongoing humanitarian protection efforts with regards to the provision of psycho-social support, health care and access to education; capacity building of civil society to ensure service delivery for survivors of GBV; and work to institutionalize and enforce legal mechanisms to ensure women's full social and political participation, including in potential peace negotiations and post-conflict reconstruction efforts. In countries undergoing political transition over the immediate, medium and long term, our actions will include: behavior change awareness and messaging through engagement with youth, men, community and religious leaders; access to economic and social resources for survivors of GBV; and, policy and legal reform regarding GBV survivors' access to justice. Potential partners may include local and/or international non-governmental and/or civil society organizations, partner governments, local educational institutions, other bilateral and multilateral donors and implementing partners.

title.narrative: Middle East Education Research, Training and Support Mechanism

description.narrative: MER programming will support research, training, and other analytical activities that address some of the most pressing education issues in the region, with a focus on the various crises and their effect on learners, teachers, education systems and education outcomes. This funding will be used to generate discussions, analyze regional trends, and inform strategic thinking and programming. The research will create new data and analysis to inform key partners' education plans for increasing access to higher quality education for all children in the region, with a particular focus on vulnerable children and youth. In particular, the activity will:Conduct continuous data collection and research on the effects of the Syria, Yemen, and Iraq crises on education for children and youth;Respond to requests for research and assessments;Undertake analytical reports and trends analysis; and,Provide capacity building, training, and technical support to USAID and its partners.
